messages.subject: BUSINESS CONTACT
messages.body:
Standard scam opener


Dear Sir, 

I am Barrister Philip Adama, a solicitor at law. I am the personal attorney to 
Mr. Ralf Lin, who used to work with Shell Development Company in Nigeria. 

On the 21st of April 2000, my client, his wife and their only daughter were 
involved in a car accident along sagbama express road. All occupants of the 
vehicle unfortunately lost there lives. Since then I have made several enquiries 
to your embassy here to locate any of my clients extended relatives, this has 
also proved unsuccessful. 

After these several unsuccessful attempts, I decided to look for any body who 
will be willing to assist me in recovering the fund valued at US$10.5 million 
left behind by my client before it gets confisicated or declared unserviceable 
by the Bank where this huge amount were deposited. 

The said Bank has issued me a notice to provide the next of kin or have the 
account confisicated within the next twenty one official working days.Since I 
have been unsuccesfull in locating the relatives for over 2 years now, I seek 
your consent to present you as the next of kin to the deceased hence I have all 
the legal document to back you up for the claim, so that the proceeds of this 
account can be paid to you. 

Therefore, on receipt of your positive response, we shall then discuss on how we 
can sharing the funds when it get into your account. I have all necessary 
information and legal documents needed to back you up for claim. All I require 
from you is your honest cooperation to enable us see this transaction through. I 
guarantee that this will be executed under legitimate arrangement that will 
protect you from any breach of the law. 

IF YOU ARE VERY MUCH READY TO PROCEED with me, THEN CONTACT ME 0N THIS E-Mail ;adamaphilip@yahoo.com


Best Regards 

Barrister Philip Adama

messages.subject: Business - Questions
messages.body:
Hi Phil

Greetings from an overcoast, wet Northwest - I guess its a sight warmer where 
you are! Great to hear from you - I can tell you with retirement next year I 
could sure use some cash. I've $50,000 saved towards my retirement home but $4.5 
million means I could set my sights higher!!

Thanks for your phone number - I may be old fashioned but I'm leery of giving 
mine out so someone I don't know. Hows about we stick with email for now?

I've had a few questions I want to run past you.

- Seems kinda hard to believe that this guy with $10 million to his name doesn't 
have any relatives. What if one turns up after we've done the deal. Guess the 
bank would put them on to me, and I sure wouldn't want anyone after me for $10 
million (specially if you have $4 million of it).

- What about my name - Munster's not even close to Lin. How will we convince 
anyone I'm next of kin? Wil I have to change my name?

- Will I need to come to Nigeria. Never been away from the Northwest - I'll have 
to get a passport. Might I catch AIDS? I've heard bad things from Nigeria - 
don't you stone people if they get their end away? Will Pamela be safe?

- Should I get an attorney to check out my end of this - I'll need one next year 
when we buy that retirement place so I guess I could start looking now.

I guess you've covered all these angles, but please put an old man's mind to 
rest.


Hope to hear from you soon,

Hal
messages.raw:
Hal Munster III

Old Hal's math is never very good - the money and his share fluctuate throughout.  As any % of nothing is nothing, Adama doesn't bother to correct.

messages.body:
Date:Tue, 21 Oct 2003 06:07:25 -0700 (PDT)
From:"Harold Munster" 
Subject:What's the next step?
To:"philip adama" <adamaphilip@yahoo.com>

Hi Phil

Just got up to walk the dog - what a lousy morning. Fog, drizzle, you name it. 
Anyway,thought I'd check email so thanks for getting back to me - it all sounds 
too good to be true but seems you've fixed everything. Thanks for the photo; I 
don't have one scanned right now but my daughter's family are coming over this 
weekend and her husband's got a digital camera so I'll get him to take a photo. 
Will it be OK if I send it this weekend?

I feel like I'm getting to trust you so I'll give you my phone number - its 
206-350 0581 and I guess you'll have to put an international code on that. Never 
been abroad so I don't know the code - sorry. It's a phone and fax combined but 
please be careful using it. I've not told Pamela about our deal and I don't know 
what she'd make of calls from Nigerai. Can't wait to get the money though - 
she's been fundraising for a new hall at her church for the last 6 months and 
has raised $35,000 of the $60,000 they need. I'm looking forward to seeing her 
face when I write a check for the difference and more!! But for now it would be 
best that I don't make any international calls - its just gonna make her nervous 
if she finds out. Email works fine - she's not got my password so we're safe.

I've been thinking that having all your money come to my bank is bound to set 
tongues wagging. We're only a small community and everyone knows everybody's 
business. Would you be able to put the money in your client account (I guess 
attorneys the world over have such things) and transfer my share bit by bit to 
me? If this woun't work, maybe I should get an out of state account. What do you 
reckon?

Sorry to keep burdening you with questions - this kind of high finance is way 
outside of my experience. I'm sure glad I've got someone I can trust to help me! 
Let me know what I need to do next (after a cold, wet walk!).

With best wishes,

Hal

Hi Phil

Another dreary morning here - thick fog. Won't be doing much today - bit of 
maintenance on the boat but that's about all. Make the most of your african 
sunshine, mate!

Thanks for your email - did you read mine where I said I wasn't sure about 
putting this sort of money through my account here. Tongues wag, you know. Do 
you have a client account we could use, then send my share bit by bit to me?

We don't go for cell phones round here - the coverage on land is patchy and when 
I'm out on the boat, forget it! I've CB back to Pamela and VHF for the 
coastguard and they do me just fine.

Let me know what you reckon about the bank account - we don't want to miss that 
deadline.

Cheers for now,

Hal

Date:Sun, 26 Oct 2003 14:21:55 -0800 (PST)
From:"Harold Munster" 
Subject:A favor
To:"philip adama" <adamaphilip@yahoo.com>

Hi Phil

Thanks for your email - sorry if I gave you a hard time but I am a little 
nervous about this whole business. Tomorrow morning I should get details of my 
new bank account, then I'll send your form to the bank.

Well, my daughter and her family have been over for the weekend and her husband 
took a photo of me. He's compressed it for the internet and I've attached it, so 
hope you get it OK.

Their visit leads to me asking a favor from you. They come from New Jersey and 
their oldest, Stacey, is at the Joseph Pillock College which is celebrating its 
bicentenery next year. If I can quote from the handout she left me: "It was in 
1804 that the wealthy wool merchant and philanthropist, Joseph Pillock, founded 
the school which grew to be today's well respected college. It was the wish of 
Joseph that the school he founded should, as well as providing a first rate 
education, promote a strong interest in the world of which the United States is 
but a part. The college is proud to still be honoring Joseph's wish 200 years 
later and to mark this, we aim to gather photographs and messages of goodwill 
from as many countries as we can." I mentioned to Stacey that I was in email 
contact with someone from Nigeria (don't worry - I said that you were hoping to 
book a few days' whale-watching on board my boat) and she said it would be 
really cool if you could send a photo of you in Nigeria, perhaps in the street 
or at a market, holding a sign saying 'I'm for Pillock College'. I said I was 
sure you'd be able to do that for her - she is so excited. If you email the 
photo to me, I'll send it straight on to her. Many thanks.

I'll look forward to hearing from you, and I'll let you know as soon as I send 
the bank their form.

with best wishes,

Hal

Dear Mr Adieyo

Many thanks for your email, the contents of which I have noted.

Firstly, I did not mean to imply any dishonesty or underhand dealing on the part 
of you or your bank. I am sure that you will act only in the best interests of 
my late cousin and I. However, you will appreciate that people's sense of 
propriety can be distorted if they are working for a client on the other side of 
the planet whose knowledge of the local culture is limited. I therefore wanted 
to make it clear, I accept unnecessarily in your case, that although I have 
authorised expenditure of up to $7,000 on legal and other costs, I expect all 
invoices to be as closely scrutinised as they would be if you were spending your 
own money. I am relieved that we see eye to eye on this and that I can rely on 
you to look after my interests.

You mentioned the need for a letter of reactivation. Please take this as a 
formal request for the bank to reactivate Mr Lin's account.

As previously advised, Mr Philip Adama is looking after my interests in this 
matter. I have full confidence in him and he has my authority to act for me. I 
have copied him in on this email; please keep him informed of your progress.

Thanks again for your help.

Yours sincerely,

Hal Munster III

messages.body:
Date:Sat, 8 Nov 2003 13:31:31 -0800 (PST)
From:"Harold Munster" 
Subject:UPS?

Hi Phil

You would be proud of me - I've made a lot of progress on this transfer.

I spoke to Mrs Kirkpatrick at Kings Market, our island general store. She had 
heard of Western Union and said that sometimes tourists ask for it to get money 
sent from home. 'You learn something new every day,' I told her. But she said 
there is no Western Union on San Juan - the nearest is Anacortez which is a 
ferry ride away and she had a feeling that only opened in the tourist season. 
Otherwise it would be the mainland - probably Seattle. At this my heart sank - 
had my boat been in the water I could perhaps have made the trip but there is no 
way I could take a ferry and be off the island all day without Pam wanting to 
know why. And I can't risk raising her suspicions if I've borrowed $7,000 of the 
church's money!

But then she said that what people had done was to use the UPS 'BondLink' 
service. I wandered down to the UPS agent and picked up a leaflet for this 
service, and having asked quite a few questions believe I understand it. It 
seems to work like this:

- It is designed for financial instruments such as bearer securities (whatever 
they are!) but he says people do use it for cash. It is ultra secure in that 
details of the consignment are kept secret and if anything does not match up, it 
is returned to sender.

- To use it, I need to get your full name (or that of the person collecting the 
consignment) and the country of issue and number of some form of photo ID (they 
recommend your passport). I then take the package and send it to a UPS agent in 
Nigeria, quoting your name and ID. The package does not get a conventional 
tracking number as the only person who can track it is me, by email progress 
reports or through the agent here in Friday Harbor.

- You go to the agent in Nigeria, show them your ID and provide the password I 
will give you. If there is a match, they will give you the package. If the 
details do not match, they will not even admit that there is a package for you 
(although they will tell me there has been an unsuccessful attempt to collect 
the package). If after 4 days the package has not been collected, it will be 
sent back to me.

This service (as you might expect) isn't cheap but seems like the only way I can 
get round the lack of Western Union on the island. Presumably you are happy for 
me to add the cost to my expenses when we divide up the £12.5 million?

If you are happy with this, can you let me have the name, ID type and number for 
the person who will be collecting the package. Can you also tell me which of 
these UPS agents is most convenient for you:

17 Olaide Tomori Street
Off Simbat Abiola Way
Ikeja
Lagos

Hallmark Bank Building
139 Broad Street
Lagos

Eleganza Plaza
1, Commercial Road
Apapa
Lagos

12 Idowu Taylor Street
Victoria Island
Lagos

I get up to 15KG for the basic fee - I know you will be coming over soon but are 
there any little gifts (perhaps for friends you are leaving behind) that you 
would like me to put in? We can get most things on the island, and I will not be 
able to get a UPS pickup until Tuesday at the earliest. Once it is on its way, I 
will tell you the arrival date and password.

I know that there is a lot of information and if anything is unclear please tell 
me. Otherwise, please let me know if you want me to go ahead and send the $7,000 
by UPS (and what else I should send).

I can just imagine the look on Pam's face when I tell her we are rich beyond our 
dreams - thanks for making this possible. And call me if you can, but if I act 
strange it is because Pam is listening!

Mail me soon, partner, I feel like we're nearly there!

Hal

messages.body:
Date:Mon, 10 Nov 2003 12:18:56 -0800 (PST)
From:"Harold Munster" 
Subject:Money
To:"philip adama" <adamaphilip@yahoo.com>

Hiya Phil

How are you - how is your day going?

At your request I've done some more research into Western Union. There 
definitely is no Western Union on the island. There is an office on a nearby 
island, Anacortes, but it closed mid October and doesn't open again til Easter. 
This means that the only option would be to get the ferry to Seattle. I've 
thought this through but there is no way I could justify a day in Seattle to 
Pam. She gets suspicious, checks the money and I'd be arrested either on the 
dock at Seattle or on my return here - certainly before I've had the chance to 
email you the transfer details. Sorry - I can't jeopardize everything now we're 
so close.

I also asked the UPS agent about the Bondlink service to Nigeria. He said that 
as far as he knew it was OK, but because of what you said I got him to check. 
Turns out you were right - the service has been suspended for the last couple 
months due to 'high levels of corruption in Nigerian customs'. I asked what the 
options where and they told me that packages were being sent to Cotonou in Benin 
which apparently is very close. They suggested I ask if you could get to Cotonou 
- if I send the money tomorrow you could pick it up on Friday. I can also put 
the watches in - is this OK with you?

I'm worried about what they say about corruption in Nigeria. Is it true? Are you 
safe? You look after yourself.

Looking forward to hearing from you.

Your friend,

Hal

Date:Tue, 11 Nov 2003 06:08:41 -0800 (PST)
From:"Harold Munster" 
Subject:Re: Money

Hi Phil

It's not quite 6 in the money, but I couldn't sleep so I got up to check my 
emails and found your two.

About sending the money from my account to that London bank, I don't think you 
understand my situation here! This is a small island and everybody knows 
everybody. I am going to borrow $7,000 in cash from the money Pam has collected 
for the church hall. If I pay that money in to any of the island banks, it only 
takes someone to notice the teller counting more than a hundred bills and 
tongues will wag. The word will get back to Pam and it will be the end of any 
plans we have. Add to that the idea of asking the teller to pay the money to a 
London bank - I don't suppose anyone has asked for that all year. They will have 
to make phone calls, get advice. People will talk and Pam will get to know. And 
how long will it take to get the money converted out of $ and into that account? 
The to get our $12m into my Citibank account. All that time I'm exposed if Pam 
gets wind anything funny is happening. That's why I came up with the UPS idea - 
nobody on the island need know I'm sending money and it is fast. But if that is 
no good to you then we will have to come up with an alternative, but handing 
over $7000 in cash while my neighbor stands in line behind me is not an option. 
I hope this makes my position clear.

I understand that my situation here is making life difficult and if you want to 
look for another partner I will understand. But if we can come up with a 
solution which does not give an unacceptable risk of discovery, I will go for 
it!

Your friend,

Hal

messages.body:
Date:Wed, 12 Nov 2003 08:49:55 -0800 (PST)
From:"Harold Munster" 
Subject:Phil please help
To:"philip adama" <adamaphilip@yahoo.com>

Hiya Phil

I've just had the worst 24 hours of my life Phil, and I'm going to need you to 
help me please!

You know I said that I was taking some tourists out for a boat trip ten days 
ago. Well I'm sorry to have to tell you that wasn't quite the truth. For about 
18 months I've been seeing Mrs Babbister who works at the town council office 
which deals with boat licensing. It's not been too serious - we get together 
maybe once, twice a month. But because she issues licenses for trip boats like 
mine, there could be a lot of ill feeling with my competitors if word got out.

Anyway, a week last Saturday Brenda and I set out for Kanaka Bay on the other 
side of the island. We had anchored and were enjoying ourselves when Bruce 
Richards, another trip boat captain, saw my boat and came alongside. In the heat 
of the moment we never noticed til he was in my cockpit. I scrambled up to see 
him and so did Brenda once she was decent - nothing was said but it wouldn't 
take a rocket scientist to work out what was going on.

We both hoped that Bruce would be discreet and so it seemed until yesterday, 
when Pam came storming back from town demanding to know what I had been doing on 
my boat with 'that woman'. I have never known her so angry. I'm afraid that in 
my panic I made up the best story I could in it included you! Remember that when 
Patsy and Michael were here for the weekend (with Stacey) I mentioned that I had 
been in touch with you - I was keeping our business secret so I told them you 
worked for the Nigerian government and were investigating whether there could be 
a whale watching industry in Nigeria. Well I told Pam that you had visited San 
Juan at the invitation of the county boat licensing office to see how we did 
things here and Mrs Babbister had invited you to spend a day on my boat 
(naturally she would accompany you). I said to Pam that once we had left Friday 
Harbor you had been overcome with sea-sickness and Mrs Babbister had taken you 
below to lie down while I looked for somewhere to anchor. Her delay in coming up 
to see Bruce and her flustered state was because she had been settling you onto 
one of the bunks and cleaning up from one particularly widespread vomiting. You 
had remained below decks because you would not want to be introduced to a 
stranger in your fragile state.

I could tell that Pam was suspicious, but she did seem to be taking in what I 
said. Then when I had finished she asked if that was all I had to say. When it 
was, she thought for a while then said 'This guy Philip, the Nigerian, you're in 
touch with him by email?' I said I was, so she said 'OK, get him to email me and 
tell me in his own words what happened.' I was momentarily speechless, but then 
said the only thing I could, which was 'yes'. So, my friend, I need one huge 
favour from you please.

Can you email Pam (pamela_munster@yahoo.co.uk) and basically tell her the story 
I gave her, but in your own words. Perhaps you can flesh it out a bit, 
explaining how Nigeria has a coastline and whales and your government thinks 
that the tourism opportunities are huge. You could explain how you flew to 
Seattle via Miami, and travelled to San Juan by ferry. Say that you spent a 
couple of nights in Mrs Miggins' guesthouse and how you enjoyed the island 
although the cold was not to your liking, and that you were sorry you didn't 
have time to visit our home but after the unfortunate incident on the boat you 
needed to rest. Finally, perhaps you could say how enthusiastic you now are 
about introducing whale watching in Nigeria. If you could do this for me, I will 
be eternally grateful.

I received your email about putting the money in a video. Right now I daren't 
move and certainly daren't touch Pam's money but with your help it will all blow 
over and as soon as it does I'll do exactly as you say.

Thank you for helping me in my time of need - I'll not forget it.

Cheers, my friend,

Hal

Date:Wed, 12 Nov 2003 15:15:46 -0800 (PST)
From:"Pamela Munster"  
Subject:Re: THANKS TO HALROLD .

Dear Mr Adama

I am so glad that your visit to our island was productive and will help develop 
a whole new industry in your country. Thank you for your kind invitation to the 
opening day; Hal and I have never been outside the United States (and rarely out 
of state) but if we can possibly join you, we will.

I was sorry to hear that you suffer from the 'mal de mer' - on the occasions I 
join Hal on his boat I find that the sea is particularly choppy off Egypt Point. 
Was this where things started to go wrong for you? I also find that eating the 
local delicacy, poached eel, before a trip is almost guaranteed to result in 
sickness. This is such a shame as Mrs Miggins is a wonder with the eels. I 
wonder if you perhaps overindulged at breakfast? I will certainly look at Mrs

This is such a shame as Mrs Miggins is a wonder with the eels. I wonder if you perhaps overindulged at breakfast? I will certainly look at Mrs Babbister in a new light now I realise how she came to your aid at such a crucial time. Where you able to see any of our whales despite your illness - reports suggest that the great blues are particularly numerous this year.

Please do let me know how the launch of whale watching goes in Nigeria. I am sure Hal will be only too happy to help in any way he can.

with best wishes,

Pamela

Date:Thu, 13 Nov 2003 09:34:58 -0800 (PST)
From:"Pamela Munster"  
Subject:We need to speak
To:"philip adama" <adamaphilip@yahoo.com>

Dear Mr Adama

Thank you for your email, and I give you credit that you did not fall into the 
obvious traps I laid in my reply to you. Nevertheless, you and I both know that 
your story about visiting this island and taking a trip with my husband is a lie 
from start to finish. I am sure you acted with the best of motives to help my 
husband, but unfortunately Hal is unaware that I know all about his little 
flings with a number of the ladies of the island of which Brenda Babbister is 
only the last. I am afraid that after 37 years of marriage I take the view that 
it is best to let him get on with it, as indeed I myself get on with it. His 
relationship with Brenda has already lasted longer than most; Hal is in every 
way a small man and struggles to satisfy anyone for more than a few months.

I haven't yet been able to get to the bottom of whatever scam you and Hal have 
between you, but I intend to find out. I do not believe that you have anything 
to do with the tourist industry so I assume that you had a business proposition 
for Hal. Let me assure you that in this household I deal with the finances and 
make the decisions, even in respect of Hal's boat and whale watching business. 
Hal has about as much business sense as our pet cat and despite the impression 
he may have given you, any deal which you may be doing is doomed to failure. If 
there is money to be made, I suggest you discuss your proposition with me.

I look forward to hearing from you.

with best wishes,

Pamela Munster
